Lack enough support: The claim that "The Simpsons" predicted the common autocorrect feature on phones, tablets, and computers lacks enough support as it is based on a visual gag in one episode of the show.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the visual gag in "The Simpsons" episode is a prediction of autocorrect, without considering alternative explanations.
Exist alternative explanation: The visual gag in "The Simpsons" episode is actually commenting on another technological innovation, handwriting recognition, rather than autocorrect.
Understate: The claim understates the fact that autocorrect already existed as a feature in Microsoft Word prior to the airing of the episode.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that autocorrect was already available in Microsoft Word and was being advertised as early as October 1993, more than a year before the episode aired.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the joke in "The Simpsons" episode, suggesting that it had a direct impact on the development of the autocorrect feature on the first iPhone.
